Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

Subject: Discharge Summary for Mr. ___  

Dear Dr. ___,

I am writing to provide a summary of Mr. ___'s hospital admission from March 10, 2024, to March 12, 2024, following a presentation of chest pain (CP) and shortness of breath (SoB).

Mr. ___, a 65-year-old male, was admitted on March 10, 2024, after arriving by ambulance with complaints of significant chest pain and difficulty breathing. Upon initial evaluation, an electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated ST elevation in leads V5-6, indicative of myocardial injury.

During his stay, Mr. ___ was diagnosed with ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) involving the left main coronary artery, as confirmed on March 11, 2024. His Troponin T levels were found to be markedly elevated, with results of 30 and 29, further corroborating the diagnosis.

In line with the MONAC protocol, immediate medical management included administration of Morphine for pain control (2-4 mg as needed), Aspirin (a single dose of 324 mg chewed for its antiplatelet effect), Nitroglycerin (0.4 mg every five minutes for a total of three doses if required), and Oxygen supplementation (2-4 L/min if oxygen saturation fell below 90%). Despite efforts to contact the catheterization lab for potential percutaneous coronary intervention, attempts were unsuccessful due to communication issues with the cardiology team, and the ST elevation persisted.

By March 12, 2024, Mr. ___ reported resolution of his chest pain and expressed a request for discharge, feeling improved from his initial presentation. In light of the clinical improvements and his stable condition, he was deemed suitable for discharge.

For continued care, it is recommended that Mr. ___ follows up with his cardiologist to assess his cardiac status and discuss long-term management strategies. Comprehensive outpatient evaluation, including further cardiac investigations and potential secondary prevention measures, should be considered.

Please feel free to reach out should there be any questions or if further clarification is required regarding Mr. ___'s hospitalization and management.

Thank you for your attention and collaboration in caring for Mr. ___.

Kind regards,

Dr. ___
